meta_data.title: Biblical Contradictions – Is It Wrong to Doubt?

transcription_data.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable, substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner, and I'm joined by Chris Legg and Bryn Starnes. This is Reconstructed Faith. Welcome back to the Reconstructed Faith podcast. My name is Colson Lechner joined as always by my partners in crime, Chris Legg and Bryn Starnes. Hey guys, doing good. We're doing great. Amazing. Wonderful. Well, we hope you out there in the podcast universe. Oh, there's a little lag. There is a little. The funny thing is though, there really wasn't much of a lag earlier. Yep. So sorry, Bryn. But although all that say we are in the That's all right. Reaching out to you in the podcast universe. We're going to continue our conversation on deconstruction when it relates to apparent contradictions in the Bible. And so we know that there's a long list of those and we're trying to handle those conversations honestly. But then also bringing truth to those conversations. But before we jump into our next apparent contradiction, Bryn had a question concerning the hiddenness of God episode that she wasn't present for. So, Bryn, can I throw it over to you and you hand us that question and then we'll move from there. Yeah. Yeah. And if there is a little delay, I apologize. I'm not at my normal recording location. Yeah. So I listened to that episode and really appreciated the conversation. This is something that I have actually heard is one of the main questions that people have currently. Like when it comes to deconstruction, a lot of times, and I can't remember who I'm quoting, but they were saying that of all the individuals they've interacted with who have been deconstructing, two of the main topics that are hardest for people right now is questions of morality. So a lot of times questions around sexuality and what the Bible says, and then what God is asking. And then the other one being the hiddenness of God. So I'm really thankful that you all covered that because it's a question that's come up a lot. But I think after listening to it, one of the questions that I had was when it comes to what we call the hiddenness of God or however you want to define it, the challenge of feeling God's presence, hearing from Him. I was thinking back to Genesis when it talks about the garden and how God walked with Adam and Eve and communed directly with them. And then after sin, they immediately went into hiding and basically hid from God. And so it broke their relationship with Him, their relationship with each other. And He says, I have to go back in Genesis, but doesn't God say, why are you hiding? I'd have to, I need to pull it up. But basically they're, but they're hiding from God. And so my thought with this hiddenness question, I think it is complex, but part of it is, do you think that a lot of times it's a perceived hiddenness that really is a result of sin in our own life and just that broken relationship? So it's not that God is making it hard for us to, or making it a lot of work for us to commune with Him. It's that sin has broken that relationship and created that division. And then also because of our sin, we choose a lot of things that push us to not invest in our relationship with the Lord, to hide from Him, to hide from the provisions that He's put in place for us to be in close relationship with Him. That, yeah, that's kind of what I've been rolling around in my head kind of thinking through. You think that's a big part of this hiddenness conversation? Yeah, I think that's a really good point. And it isn't the direction we naturally went because we were really focusing on God's hiddenness, that there is a sense in which God does not fully reveal Himself and why that would be. I mentioned Sunday about, we're talking about the charismatic people and how charismatic the devil must be and that kind of stuff. And just like that, the devil may crank up his charisma to 100% and humans certainly do every time we get, every tense we get, we crank up our charisma as high as we can. But how fascinating it is that God doesn't do that, that God doesn't crank up his charisma to full because if He did, no one would then have any freedom because His personality would overwhelm ours immediately. And it's intriguing that that's a gentleness in God to not overwhelm us with His presence all the time. Now, that being said, yeah, I think probably sometimes there is something about God that is hidden. And I think sometimes we just have our eyes closed or our eyes covered. And I think that's a really good point, Bryn, that I think people close their eyes and then complain about God's hiddenness. I think that's a very real thing. Or they won't accept anything but what they already have in mind. They're angry or they're hurting or whatever. And so anything that would seem to defend the idea of a God who loves them, they're not interested in that input. Only information that then backs their resentment or their pain, that's what they look to, which again is understandable. But I think it's not the whole picture. But I even think in my own life, not even, I mean, we definitely make choices that are, you know, that we're aware of. But I also think like the effect of sin on the rest of me also impacts my ability to feel God's presence and commune with Him. So the fact that I am, you know, don't have a lot of patience or I'm a distracted person or I'm, you know, whatever it is like about being a human, I'm not able to pray for long periods of time. I want to do things in my own strength so I don't take my problems to Him anyway. You know, like all of these things about being a broken human, I know for me, they're, I mean, if I am not actively seeking to spend time with Him, it's like any relationship like we talk about. If I'm not actively seeking to spend time with Him, then yeah, I feel in His absence, but it's not that He's gone anywhere. It's like a result of my choices, not that I don't want to be close to Him, but I've chosen things that have created that separation. Does that make sense? Yeah, for sure. It's a, there is a sense that the personal relationship that, you know, I may say I want to have a close relationship with my wife, but if I'm flirting with other women or having relationships with other women, I am not going to have the same relationship or... We're just ignoring your... Yeah, yeah, even ignoring her. Yeah, exactly. Those are going to change that. You know, there's a famous old story that a lot of pastors tell about, you know, the old married couple driving down the road in a pickup truck and in front of them, they see there's a couple, you know, the bench seat and the old pickup trucks. They don't make those anymore, really, but the bench seats, they used to be in old pickup trucks and the guy is sitting behind the steering wheel and in this car, in this truck, there's some young couple and the girl is sitting right pressed up against him in the middle, not on the far right. And the wife turned, the old woman turns to her husband, she's like, how come we don't sit like that anymore? And the old husband says, I haven't moved. And that whole story is meant to connect to that exactly what you're describing. There are times we go, I feel like God's a long way. He's far away from me or he's distant from me. And God's going, I haven't moved. You moved and you went away from me and you ran from me or you're not interested in communicating with me or whatever. And so of course we feel more disconnected or less connected to anyone, including God, who we flee from or who we avoid or who we bear resentment toward that we're not willing to concede that. And so it's not an easy thing. I'm not saying that, well, so therefore stop feeling what you're feeling, but it is good to know this is probably what this is about. I think I've told you guys about, I had some really good friends. He was a pastor and she was a counselor and they had been praying for a baby. They had been unable to have a child, been praying for a baby for 10 years. And then she got pregnant and then they had a miscarriage. And they kind of in horrible grief called us and Ginger and I went to go spend the day with them. And at one point the husband is like, I don't doubt that there is a God, but I'm certainly not on speaking terms with him right now. And I think that's a natural emotional response. And we have to figure out, am I willing at some point to come back into relationship with this God who has disappointed me so badly? And so, you know, to, to pretend like you're not doubting is not an improvement over doubting. Um, cause I think that's a, so often that is an issue, um, that, that you, when you actually stop and look at the passage and you go, wait, this, this doesn't, even this doesn't say that if I, that if I don't, if I ever asked for anything and I doubt God won't give it to me, like none of that is here. There's ways that you can understand why people feel like, oh, this is saying I better not doubt. Okay. But, but what's going to happen? Like every step of it needs to be engaged with to see does it, does it say that or not? And if it, if it doesn't, what is it saying and wrestle with that? Like it is a great thing to have to wrestle with what scripture actually says. And that's hard enough. Let's not make it say something else. And then have to wrestle with that. Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith. If you enjoy what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource of South spring Baptist church. Remember don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.

She's like, no, no, I don't want to get Mexican. And they do this whole conversation like that. And
you're like, and this is what he's asking. Like, why did, why did you ask? I would love to know.
Could we go back to the original question? I'd love to be at least understand the motivation for
why you asked me. And I actually got to explain it to him that it has to do more with
helping her organize her thoughts and, and, and to figure out what she really wants and all that
kind of stuff. And that it really can be valuable, but still it's like, yeah, God,
what would you have me do in this situation? Well, my word speaks clearly to it. And here's
the spirit's guidance. And I mean, anything but that, what else you got? A special word for me.
Exactly. Can I get something different? Anyway, interesting. Yeah. Actually, an angel appeared
to me and told me that I can disobey God's word. That's exactly right. That's right.
And also we're having Mexican food. Exactly. And we say this so many times, but I think it's
worth mentioning. I think all this once again, goes back to the character of God, where it's like
this verse, which is why we're digging into it, but this verse seems to say, you know,
if you read it a certain way, Hey, you can't doubt. But then you see like God's patience
with his people throughout the whole Bible of like, um, you know, Job and all the different
people who are wrestling, uh, Thomas and, you know, just people who have wrestled with questions.
And he is so patient with them. And, um, you know, which is it Elijah or Elisha, the one who, um,
once he goes to the cave, Elijah, where, um, he's, yeah, he goes to the cave yesterday. Yeah.
Yeah. And he just is like, just saw God work in so many ways and then is struggling with
probably doubt of some kind because he, it seems that he's depressed. And anyway,
just like seeing God's patience over and over and over again with his people and yes, calling him to
calling them to his word and what he's told them, but still kindness and, and bearing with them,
you know, and then scripture saying that he is the same yesterday, today and forever.
And so just going back to the character of God saying, even if this one verse seems to say like,
Hey, you're not allowed to doubt at all. That's not, um, we have to look at the big picture once
again of the character of God and, and the picture that scripture is painting of him when it comes to
us wrestling with him and our ability to do that, you know. I think that's a great point. Did you
have an additional point, Chris? Well, I think, I think what struck me too was it's, we do want
people to know that of course we doubt. And even if it is not a good idea, it's sometimes too doubt.
That doesn't mean we're not sometimes going to. And so, you know, to, to pretend like you're not
doubting is not an improvement over doubting. Um, and so to, to wrestle with it, I think is a good
thing, but let, I think this could be an encouragement to people that when, that when people say, um,
like there's this passage in the Bible and it causes this huge problem for me to go, okay,
well first I really, really want to encourage you to go actually look at that passage and really
dig into it. Um, cause I think that's a, so often that is an issue, um, that, that you, when you
actually stop and look at the passage and you go, wait, this, this doesn't, even this doesn't say
that if I, that if I don't, if I ever asked for anything and I doubt God won't give it to me,
like none of that is here. There's ways that you can understand why people feel like,
oh, this is saying I better not doubt. Okay. But, but what's going to happen? Like every step of it
needs to be engaged with to see does it, does it say that or not? And if it, if it doesn't,
what is it saying and wrestle with that? Like it is a great thing to have to wrestle with what
scripture actually says. And that's hard enough. Let's not make it say something else.
And then have to wrestle with that.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith. If you enjoy what you heard
or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info
at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource of South spring Baptist church.
Remember don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
